title: How Water Channels Transform Farming Forever

subtasks: Sitting on the tractor seat
Moving arms to operate hydraulic levers
Tilting the hay loader to load hay into the baler
Pressing the pedal to engage the baler's power take-off (PTO)
Observing the bale sizes and adjusting as needed
Ensuring the baler is filling the bale correctly
Steering the tractor to follow the baler
Adjusting speed to match the baler's operation
Observing bale quality and removing rejects
Stacking the bales in the designated area
Securing the bales onto a trailer for transport
Stopping the tractor and baler to turn around
Retracting the baler to a safe position
Positioning the baler to start a new row or field
Checking hydraulic fluid levels
Inspecting for any parts wear or damage during operation
Cleaning the baler of debris after use
Clearing the area of uneven terrain or obstacles
Ensuring bales are placed in a stable manner
Marking the stack location for easy reference
Removing the tarp or cover from the bale stack
Inspecting the bales for moisture damage
Distributing the bales to the appropriate storage or feeding areas
